metadata.title: The Transformation of the Canadian Domestic Servant, 1871-1931

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the decline of domestic service as a paid occupation and its replacement by unpaid housework, driven by technological changes in household management.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on domestic servants in Canada, particularly in urban areas, using census data from 1871, 1881, and 1901.

dependent_variables.displaced: The decline of domestic service as a paid occupation.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Domestic servants' earnings did not keep pace with other occupations, leading to a decline in the occupation.

text_fragments: 'I'd rather pick rags and keep my self-respect!' Such was the reaction of one Canadian woman who faced the prospect of becoming a domestic servant in the early twentieth century.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the transformation of domestic service from a paid occupation to unpaid housework, influenced by technological changes and demographic shifts.

technological_changes: introduction of household appliances like vacuum cleaners and washing machines
historical_context.economic_conditions: The study covers a period of economic growth and industrialization in Canada.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses labor market conditions and the role of immigration in the labor supply for domestic service.

outcomes.main_findings: Domestic service declined as a paid occupation due to technological changes and demographic shifts, leading to its replacement by unpaid housework.
outcomes.conclusions: The decline of domestic service was not just a reduction in employment but a transformation of the work process, influenced by technological and demographic changes.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The decline of paid domestic service led to the rise of unpaid housework, affecting women's labor roles.
